newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's DKB faces more tough times over scandal.
newsitem.headline: Japan's DKB faces more tough times over scandal.

text.p: A widening racketeer payoff scandal could ensnare top executives at Japan's Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd (DKB), and analysts say the bank needs to take drastic steps to repair damage to its reputation from the affair.

Public outrage over the scandal has forced DKB, Japan's second-largest bank in terms of deposits, to cancel initial plans for a management reshuffle and bank sources said on Sunday that a new line-up would be unveiled in a few days.

The original plan would have promoted vice president Ichiro Fujita to the post of president, but it was scuttled, a bank source said, in part due to fears of further arrests linked to the bank's loans to a "sokaiya" racketeer.

Last Thursday, prosecutors arrested four DKB officials on suspicion of extending uncollateralised loans to Ryuichi Koike, the racketeer at the heart of a scandal which has also ensnared giant Nomura Securities Co Ltd.

Dai-Ichi Kangyo said on May 23 that its president Katsuhiko Kondo and chairman Tadashi Okuda would resign their posts and become advisers, and be replaced by Fujita and another vice-president, Yoshiharu Mani. The bank had defended its choice of Fujita, who has admitted he knew of the loans.

The bank's top management appeared to have misjudged both the level of public anger and authorities' reaction to the scandal, which emerged just as Japan gears up for "Big Bang" financial reforms aimed at introducing greater competition into the nation's banking, broking and insurance industries.

"What is really surprising is the way that DKB management is handling this," said James McGinness, a banking analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson International. "I think they underestimated the damage that could be done."

In contrast, Nomura early in the saga announced a broad management shake-up that put corporate youngster Junichi Ujiie, 51, in the president's post and removed 15 executives including five vice presidents from its board.
"Practice makes perfect," said one analyst, referring to Nomura's experience with a similar scandal six years years ago.
Ten arrests have already been made in the scandal, including Nomura's former president Hideo Sakamaki, three other Nomura executives and the four DKB officials.

Prosecutors have mobilised some 50 investigators, more than in the late 1980s Recruit shares-for-favours affair which brought down then-prime minister Noboru Takeshita, in a probe focusing on possible involvement by top DKB executives, Japanese media said.
Domestic media said prosecutors would soon investigate a former DKB vice president and several other top bank officials and that further criminal complaints were being contemplated.
In addition, both DKB and Nomura face as yet unspecified administrative penalties which could include the suspension of some business for a period of several months.
Both institutions are suffering from client defections and are being distracted from forward-looking strategic planning by the need for damage control, analysts said.
But some optimists said the two firms could turn adversity into opportunity if they took the right steps.
"DKB doesn't seem to be doing anything really positive to resolve the situation," said Brian Waterhouse, financial analyst at HSCB James Capel.
"But if the result is that a whole generation of bankers is swept away and they get a lot of new blood with new ideas for the future, it could end up quite positive for DKB," he said.
